column1: The Doshisha Corporation (English: The Doshisha) is the educational corporation to which Doshisha University and Doshisha Women's College belong.

Doshisha was founded in 1875 by Joseph Hardy Neesima as a Christian Protestant (Congregational) school based on Christian principles, and is a comprehensive educational institution with nine educational facilities bearing the name "Doshisha" from university to kindergarten (as of April 2005).
As of April 2004, approximately 36,000 people are studying at Doshisha University.
Currently, Doshisha Educational Corporation has obtained <AA+> from Rating and Investment Information, Inc. (R&I).
<AA+> is the second highest rating out of 21 levels.
Alongside Waseda University and Keio University, it is one of the top school corporations.
The founding spirit of Doshisha University is "conscience" based on the Christian spirit.
Shinshiro Shimazaki aimed to cultivate individuals who could utilize their conscience in their actions as the purpose of education.
I wanted to produce people who are "filled with conscience" by promoting "moral education" based on Christianity in parallel with education that does not lean towards knowledge education.
Monuments engraved with his handwriting, expressing his thoughts, can be found at various schools such as Doshisha University.
The words "May the whole body be filled with conscience and courage" are engraved on this monument.

Furthermore, in order to concretely realize this "education of conscience," educational principles of "Christianity," "liberalism," and "internationalism" are advocated, aiming to produce individuals who embody the "conscience of a nation" through these principles.
It is a Protestant school corporation with a congregational church (union church) background.

However, it is different in nature from so-called mission-based universities and does not have as its primary purpose the spread of Christianity (it does not use education itself as a means of evangelism).
A school corporation that originated from the Doshisha English School, established by one of the six great educators of the Meiji era, Joseph Hardy Neesima, in 1875.
In 1875, J.C. Hepburn founded Doshisha English School in Marutamachi, Teramachi, Kyoto.
In 1876, it moved from Teramachi to Imadegawa.
In April 1877, the Doshisha branch school for women was established, and in September it was renamed the Doshisha Women's School.
Establishment of the Doshisha University Regulations in 1883.
In 1888, the "Purpose of Establishing Doshisha University" was announced in major newspapers and magazines nationwide.
In 1896, the ordinary school was renamed Doshisha High School.
Established the Doshisha Junior High School.
In 1897, M.F. Denton opened the Demachi Kindergarten.
In 1900, Shutchou Kindergarten was renamed to Imadegawa Kindergarten.
In 1904, theological schools and vocational schools were established under the Vocational School Order.

In 1912, Doshisha University (preparatory school, theology department, political economy department, English department) and Women's School Specialized Department (English department, home economics department) were established under the Vocational School Law.
Doshisha University was established in 1920 under the University Ordinance.
Ikkyu Sojun was a Zen monk of the Rinzai sect of the Rinzai sect Daitoku-ji school during the Muromachi period.
Known as a model of speech.

Regarding "Ikkyu-san no Tonchi Banashi," please refer to the section on "Ikkyu Banashi" (there is also some description on this page). For information on the TV anime "Ikkyu-san," please refer to the section on "Ikkyu-san."
Born in Kyoto, said to be a descendant of Emperor Go-Komatsu.
In the diary of Sugawara Nagamasa, "Diary of Tohojo Nagamasa" on August 1, 1494, it is written: "It is said in secret that Ikkyu Sojun is the illegitimate child of Emperor Gohanazono."
"There is no one in the world who knows it."
According to later historical records, his childhood name was Chigikumaru.
He was later called Zhou Jian, and went by the aliases Kuang Yunzi, Xialu, and Mukei.
The posthumous Buddhist name is Soshun, also written as Soshun.
Ikkyu is a Buddhist monk's title.
Please refer to the "posthumous Buddhist name" section for information on posthumous Buddhist names and dharma names.
At the age of 6, he entered the Ankokuzan Shingon Temple in Kyoto and received the precepts, and was named Zhou Jian.

From an early age, he excelled in poetry, and his Chinese poems "Nagato Spring Grass" composed at the age of 13 and "Spring Clothes Lodging Flowers" composed at the age of 15 became renowned and praised in the capital city of Kyoto.
In the 17th year of Oei (1410), at the age of 17, he became a disciple of Ken'o Sui and changed his Buddhist name to Soshun.
At this time, it cannot be determined whether Ikkyu's behavior is due to his master's passing, but he has attempted suicide.
In the 22nd year of Ōei (1415), he became a disciple of Kasō Sōdon, a high priest at Daitoku-ji in Kyoto.

In response to the koan "The stick of Dongshan's three pounds," he answered, "Returning from non-being to being, take a rest. When it rains, let it rain. When the wind blows, let it blow." Because of this, he received the Dharma name of Ikkyu from Kaso.
"Arroji (world of defilements)" refers to the world of delusion (worldly desires), while "muroji (world of enlightenment)" refers to the world of enlightenment (Buddha).
One night in the 27th year of the Ōei era (1420), upon hearing the cawing of a crow, I suddenly have a great realization.
The old man tried to give a letter of approval to Ikkyu, but he declined.
It is said that the old man sent him off laughing as a fool.
In the future, I lived a life of poetry, tanka, calligraphy, and eccentricity.
In the first year of Shōchō (1428), Emperor Shōkō passed away without leaving a male heir, and Emperor Go-Hanazono was welcomed from the Fushimi-no-miya family and ascended to the throne.
It is said that Ikkyu recommended the enthronement of Emperor Go-Hanazono.
From "The Biography of Ikkyu Sojun in the Tokai Region".
However, Imaizumi Yoshio claims that the enthronement of Go-Hanazono was approved by the shogunate and was not related to Ikkyu's recommendation.

In the 6th year of the Bunmei era following the Ōnin War (1474), he was appointed as the head priest of Daitoku-ji by the decree of Emperor Go-Tsuchimikado, the 47th head priest. Though he did not reside in the temple, he devoted himself to its revival.
The Kyoto Imperial Palace (Kyoto Gosho) is the imperial residence located in Kamigyo-ku, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Due to the Tokyo procession of the Meiji Restoration, the Emperor moved to the Imperial Palace in Tokyo (formerly Edo Castle), and it was preserved in the 10th year of Meiji (1877).
After the Meiji era, it was also called the Kyoto Imperial Palace.
Originally, the official Imperial Palace in Heian-kyo was located in the central part of Heian-kyo, but it was moved to the Rikyu Palace due to destruction caused by wars and other factors.

The Togu Palace of the Tsuchimikado East Daidairi was one of the palaces in this village, where the imperial family of the Jomyo-in line, later known as the Northern Court, resided throughout generations.
By the way, the imperial palace of the Daikakuji lineage, which came to be called the Southern Court, was located at Nijo Tomikoji Uchiraku.
The modern Kyoto Imperial Palace is not the same as the Doigomon Higashidoin Palace itself, but is an expansion based on the Doigomon Higashidoin Palace.
Usually, you can visit by applying, and it is open to the public in spring and autumn.
The Kyoto Imperial Palace was the residence and office of successive emperors until the imperial procession to Tokyo in 1869, the second year of the Meiji era.
The Kyoto Imperial Palace in the present day (21st century) is state-owned property classified as "Imperial property" under the jurisdiction of the Imperial Household Agency.

Adjacent to Kyoto Imperial Palace and Sentō Imperial Palace, and across the street to the north on Imadegawa Street are Doshisha University and Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts (both campuses are located on Imadegawa Street).

Currently, the Imperial Household Agency manages the Kyoto Imperial Palace, Kyoto Sento Imperial Palace, and the Sento Imperial Palace, while the Ministry of the Environment manages the Kyoto Gyoen National Garden surrounding them.
Residents of Kyoto often simply refer to the Kyoto Imperial Palace as "Gosho," including the Kyoto Imperial Garden.

However, unlike castles in foreign countries, the walls surrounding the Imperial Palace are not very high. Some argue that this difference reflects the varying levels of familiarity between the common people and rulers (such as the Emperor and the imperial family) in the East and the West.

For example, during the French Revolution, there was an incident where commoners invaded the Palace of Versailles, which was the residence of the ruler (king). Such incidents have not occurred in Japan, which is one of the bases for this analysis.

The original Imperial Palace of Heian-kyo was located considerably to the west of the current Kyoto Imperial Palace, near the Nijo Station of West Japan Railway, at the northeast corner of the Senbon Marutamachi intersection.

The current Kyoto Imperial Palace was originally one of the residences of the retired Emperor, called the Tsuchimikado Higashifushimi-no-miya, and was first used by Emperor Kogon of the Northern Court in the first year of the Genko era (1331).

The Imperial Palace that was here was rebuilt eight times only during the Edo period (six of which were rebuilt due to fires), and the existing building was reconstructed in the late Edo period in the second year of Ansei (1855) in the Heian style, known as the Ansei Imperial Palace.

In the 10th year of Meiji (1877), Emperor Meiji, who had moved to the Imperial Palace in Tokyo, visited Kyoto and lamented the deteriorating state of the Kyoto Imperial Palace, which had fallen into disrepair within 10 years of his visit to Tokyo. He ordered for the preservation of the palace and the maintenance of its former appearance.
The main buildings include the Shishin-den, Seiryo-den, Kogosho, Ogakumonjo, Tsunegoten, Koushun, Osuzumisho, and the Empress's Palace.

The enthronement ceremony has been traditionally held at the Shishin-den in the Kyoto Imperial Palace for generations, and even after the Emperor moved to Tokyo during the Meiji Restoration, it was stipulated by the 1889 Imperial Household Law that the enthronement ceremony and the Daijosai ceremony should be held in Kyoto. Both Emperor Taisho and Emperor Showa also conducted their enthronement ceremonies at the Kyoto Imperial Palace.

Furthermore, there is no specific provision in the current Imperial Household Law established after World War II that the enthronement ceremony must be held in Kyoto. In 1990, for the first time in history, the enthronement ceremony for the current Emperor was held at the Imperial Palace in Tokyo.

During the enthronement ceremony, the Emperor sits on the Takamikura, the official throne of the Emperor symbolizing the enthronement, which is located in the Shishin-den Hall of the Kyoto Imperial Palace. Therefore, for the current Emperor's enthronement ceremony, known as the "Sokuiden no Gi" (equivalent to the "Shishin-den no Gi"), the Takamikura was temporarily moved to the Imperial Palace.

Gagaku is one of the traditional music of Japan, China, the Korean Peninsula, and Vietnam.
The following will focus on Japanese gagaku transmitted to the Imperial Household Agency Shikibu Department Music Department (Important Intangible Cultural Property).
The original meaning of gagaku is "elegant and correct music and dance," contrasting with "popular music."

According to the definition by the Imperial Household Agency Shikibu-shoku Gakubu, it refers to the repertoire performed by the Imperial Household Agency Shikibu-shoku Gakubu, excluding Western music.
Many of them have been inherited as court music in instrumental music.
It is the oldest form of traditional music in the world that is still performed in large ensemble formats today.

However, as a form of ensemble music, Gagaku had been discontinued for over 100 years since the Onin War until the Tokugawa shogunate gathered the descendants of musicians (Gagakuka) and reorganized it, so it is questionable how much of the Heian period form has been inherited.

When singing the sheet music written in katakana for the biwa, it is speculated that the pronunciation of the Ha-row is pronounced as Fa Fi Fu Fe Fo, faithfully reproducing the characteristics of Japanese pronunciation before the 16th century, making it quite accurate overall.

Things written in kanji, like the notation of the raku biwa, share many similarities with the biwa scores found in Dunhuang, China, and many styles passed down from even older continents are further inherited.
One of the most important historical sources is the "Taigen Shō" written by Toyohara Tsunemasa (1450-1512), who was concerned about the dispersal of records such as gagaku due to the Ōnin War.
Tsuneaki, the head of the Shakuhachi family, compiled records on Gagaku and Bugaku centered around the shakuhachi, making it a valuable record of ancient Gagaku.
The music for rituals that originated from China, the Korean Peninsula, and South Asia before the 10th century.
In China, ya-yüe was music performed at ceremonies.

However, among the pieces currently performed in Japanese gagaku, Tang music, which is said to have been transmitted from China, is said to be based on the music played at a banquet called Yan music in the Tang Dynasty.

In terms of music categories, there are various international names such as Tang music, Goryeo music, and Linyi music (music of Champa), reflecting the diverse cultural influences. Additionally, elements of ancient Japanese music prior to the introduction of continental music have also been incorporated.

Before modern times, the Sanpogakuso were considered the three main music halls that preserved the oldest styles: Tennoji Gakuso at Shitennoji Temple in Osaka, Dainai Gakuso at the Imperial Palace in Kyoto, and Nanto Gakuso at Kasuga Taisha Shrine in Nara.

These musical institutions were called to Tokyo in modern times, forming the foundation of the current music department of the Imperial Household Agency, but the traditions of each institution continue in their respective regions.
In addition, mutual influences can be seen between folk songs and haiku, and Japan's unique style has been created.
Currently, about 100 songs have been inherited by the Imperial Household Agency Music Department.

Emperor Kanmu (737-806) was the 50th emperor of Japan.
Emperor Kanmu was born as the first son of Prince Shirakabe (later Emperor Kōnin) in the 9th year of Tenpyō (737).
Koya Shinkasa, the mother, is recorded in the Nihon Shoki as a descendant of the Baekje royal family, descended from King Munju of Baekje.
Empress Fujiwara no Otomuro gave birth to Prince Yasudono (later Emperor Heijō), and Empress Fujiwara no Tabiko gave birth to Prince Ōtomo (later Emperor Junna).

Even after his father, the White Wall King, ascended to the throne, Prince Taishi was not desired to be the crown prince because his mother, Takano Shinkasa, belonged to the low-ranking immigrant clan of the Wa clan. Initially, he aimed for career advancement as a bureaucrat, serving as a chamberlain, head of the university, and minister of the center.

However, due to political disputes involving the Fujiwara clan, the former Crown Prince and his mother, Empress Inoue, were suddenly deposed and the younger half-brother was enthroned as Crown Prince on January 2, 773.
In order to avoid the growing influence of the Nara Buddhist temples in Heijokyo, the capital was moved to Yamashiro Province.
In 784, Nagaoka-kyo was built, but in 794, Heian-kyo was built again.
To invade the Tohoku region and subjugate the Emishi, a military force was sent with Sakanoue no Tamuramaro as the commander.
However, in his later years, he was criticized by Fujiwara no Yoshitsugu of the Fujiwara clan for causing suffering to the peasants with such military actions and construction projects.
It is said that he proposed the compilation of the Nihon Shoki in terms of culture.
Saicho and Kukai returned from Tang China and brought new developments to Japanese Buddhism under the rule of Emperor Kanmu.

The unnatural deaths of Princess Inoue and Prince Hata, as well as the dark aspect of sentencing Prince Hayari to exile in 785 for the assassination of Fujiwara Tanetsugu at the beginning of his reign, also characterized his rule.

Out of fear of vengeful spirits, on July 19, 800, in the 19th year of Enryaku, Prince Sawara was posthumously named Emperor Sudo, and Princess Inoue's tomb was also designated as a mausoleum, restoring her position as Empress.

While known as the protectors of Saicho and Kukai, existing Buddhist sects have been pressured by the excessive power held by the government, resulting in measures such as confiscation of their land and other forms of oppression against the so-called "Six Schools of Nanto."
It is also said that the disorder in the inner palace led to the later "Incident at Yaxi," becoming a breeding ground for it.
He passed away on March 17, 806, in the 25th year of the Enryaku era.
Emperor Jimmu, who was given the posthumous name Yamato Takeru Ihare no Mikoto, established the Japanese imperial lineage.
Along with this, Emperor Kanmu was posthumously given the title in the Chinese style.
Kashiwabara Emperor, also known as Tenkoku Oshihata no Mikoto Kashiwabara Tenno.
The tomb is said to be the Kasihawabara Mausoleum (Kashiwabara no Misasagi) in Momoyama-cho, Fushimi-ku, Kyoto City.
Before his death, he was insistent on being buried in Utono, but due to various reasons, he was buried in Fushimi's Kashiwabara Mausoleum.
In the Meiji era, the first emperor of Heian-kyo was enshrined at Heian Shrine.
All emperors are enshrined in one of the three Imperial Mausoleums at the Imperial Palace.

On December 18, 2001, before the Emperor's birthday, which has become a tradition, Akihito made a statement during a press conference regarding the co-hosting of the FIFA World Cup the following year, saying, "I feel a connection with the Republic of Korea as it is recorded in the Nihon Shoki that the mother of Emperor Kanmu was a descendant of King Munmu of Baekje."
This statement was not widely covered in Japan, but it was extensively reported in the South Korean media and became a topic of discussion.
Some media outlets have made sensational claims such as "The Imperial Family has Korean ancestry" and "The theory of the Imperial Family's Baekje origins."
The Otani family (Otanike) is the family name of the descendants of Kakuei, the son of Kakushin-ni and Hino Hirotuna.

Hino Hirotsuna was a lower-ranking noble in Kyoto, while Kakushinni was the daughter of Shinran, who inherited the position of head priest (hōshu) of the Jōdo Shinshū sect's main temple, Higashi Honganji.

When surnames became mandatory during the Meiji era, both the head priests of the Jodo Shinshu Honganji sect (Nishi Honganji) and the head priests of the Shinshu Otani sect (Shinshu Honbyo), which split in 1602, took on surnames.
The origin of the Otani surname is due to the fact that the mausoleum of Shinran, mentioned later, was established in the Otani area north of the Chion-in Temple's gate in Higashiyama, Kyoto.

Hongan-ji was considered one of the daimyo (feudal lords) of the Sengoku period in Japan due to its power as a result of the spread of the Ikko Ikki movement. It is common to refer to the head priest with the temple's name attached, such as "Hongan-ji Kennyo" or "Hongan-ji Kosa," but this is simply for convenience and does not mean that the head priest's family lineage made Hongan-ji their surname. There was no family name or surname of Hongan-ji.
Kakushin-ni watched over Shinran's deathbed in 1262, and in 1272, she built a hall to enshrine his remains in Otani near their home in Higashiyama, Kyoto.
Daibutsu-do became a place of worship for the followers of Jodo Shinshu as Shinran's mausoleum, and Kakuei, the eldest son of Kakushin-ni, was appointed as the caretaker to manage it in his absence.

However, the Otani mausoleum later became a source of conflict between the disciples of various provinces, as they competed for pilgrimages and donations. This led to a dispute between Kakuei's son Kakunyo and his half-brother Yosho, with Kakunyo narrowly emerging victorious and establishing the hereditary succession of the mausoleum within his own family line.
In 1312, Kakunyo converted the mausoleum into a temple, giving birth to the Jodo Shinshu sect.

Since then, the descendants of Kakunyo inherited the Honganji Temple and advanced the formation of the sect. By the time of the 5th generation Jitsunyo in the Muromachi period, the Honganji sect had expanded to the Hokuriku region, and by the time of the 7th generation Sonnyo, the Honganji sect had been formed in Kaga, Noto, Echizen, Omi, and other provinces.

However, compared to other lineages of Jodo Shinshu that have been working on forming a religious organization since the death of Shinran, the formation of the organization was significantly delayed. In the early Muromachi period, Honganji was considered a sub-temple of Seiren-in, and it is said that the Otani family, through their connection to the Hino family (Shinran's birth family), also served as stewards for the Kujo family.

In the latter half of the 15th century, due to the activities of Rennyo, who became the 8th head priest, the Honganji sect spread throughout Japan. However, in 1465, the main Honganji temple was destroyed and the head priest moved to Yoshizaki in Echizen, and then to the Yamashina district on the outskirts of Kyoto.

Against the backdrop of the expansion of the teachings during the time of Rennyo in Kaga, the Kaga Ikko Ikki occurred in 1488, leading to the expulsion of the guardian Tomogashi family by the Honganji sect in Kaga, resulting in the emergence of a situation known as the "country ruled by peasants."
For approximately one hundred years until 1580, it became a country ruled by the Ikko sect.

In the 16th century, amidst the chaos of the Warring States period, the Honganji sect, starting from small farmers, utilized its organizational strength to expand its activities throughout Japan, reaching the warrior class such as samurais and local lords. However, the Yamashina Honganji temple suffered from the Tenbun Hokke Disturbance in 1532, and the 10th head, Shonyo, relocated to the Ishiyama Gobo established by Rennyo in Nishinaru-gun, Settsu Province (present-day Osaka City), renaming it Ishiyama Honganji.
Ishiyama Hongan-ji was located on the top of a hill at the northern end of the Kamimachi Plateau.
The key point of river transportation at the mouth of the Yodogawa River was controlled by Osaka.
Based in Ishiyama Hongan-ji, Shonin sought to strengthen ties with various daimyo, the shogunate, and the imperial court, stabilizing the power base of Hongan-ji.

On the other hand, from the end of the era of Shonin, in local Jodo Shinshu sects such as in Hokuriku, there were individuals who were starting to walk their own path outside of the control of Honganji.

During the time of the 11th head, Kenju, of the Shonin school, the Honganji sect, which had effectively become an independent daimyo power, expanded into the Kinai region and came into conflict with Oda Nobunaga, who sought to establish unified control by taking away lordship power from religious forces.

The conflict between the Honganji Temple and the Oda clan, which lasted for ten years from 1570, known as the Ishiyama War, saw the Honganji Temple, fortified at Ishiyama, joining forces with followers resisting the Oda clan in various regions. This alliance allowed the Honganji Temple to gain the upper hand and greatly trouble Nobunaga.

However, in 1574, Ganjoji Temple in Nagashima-cho, Ise Province (Mie Prefecture) was destroyed by the Oda clan, and in 1575, the Ikkō-ikki that recaptured Echizen from the Oda clan was annihilated, weakening resistance in various regions. In 1578, the Mori clan's navy, allied with Honganji Temple, was defeated by the Oda navy in the Battle of Kizu River, marking a series of defeats for Honganji Temple outside its walls.

While maintaining its strength by gathering support from the Iga clan and others, Hongan-ji gradually became isolated among its enemies. In 1580, it finally succumbed to Nobunaga, who obtained an imperial decree from Emperor Ogimachi, and retreated from Ishiyama Hongan-ji. The power of Hongan-ji as a feudal lord disappeared.

At this time, the eldest son Norikata and Kenyo, who advocated continuing to resist against Kenyo's intentions, disagreed. When Kenyo passed away in 1593, his third son Junyo was appointed as his successor.

From this point on, Hongan-ji began to walk the path of division over the position of the head priest, and in 1602 Tokugawa Ieyasu granted a separate temple ground to Kyonyo in addition to Junyo, splitting the Hongan-ji sect into two, with the establishment of Higashi Hongan-ji.
At this time, many followers from the Jodo sect led by Junjo, who became the head of Nishi Honganji, moved to the guidance of Kyonyo at Higashi Honganji, causing Honganji to split into east and west.

Shinran, originally the son of Hino Arinori, a court noble, and the head of the Eastern and Western Tani families, who descended from Hino Hirotsun (the father of Kakunyo), have a tradition of becoming adopted sons of powerful court nobles, and have continued to intermarry with court nobles for generations, leading to the advancement of their lineage through the maternal line.

This corresponds to the area east of the Sumida River in the current Saitama Prefecture and Tokyo, excluding islands, as well as the northeastern part of Kanagawa Prefecture (the entire area of Kawasaki City and the eastern and coastal areas of Yokohama City).

Heian-kyo was established as the capital of Japan by Emperor Kammu in the year 794 (Enryaku 13).

Heian-kyo was built in the area that now corresponds to the central part of Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture, spanning the Katsura District and the Atago District in Yamashiro Province. It was a capital city that was divided into a rectangular shape measuring 4.5km east to west and 5.2km north to south.

Establishing the Imperial Palace at the northern central part of the capital, and from there, creating the Suzaku Avenue to divide the city into the districts of Rokkaku (on the east side) and Ukyo (on the west side).
The layout plan is basically based on Heijokyo, following the example of Chang'an in the Sui and Tang dynasties.
However, there were no city walls.
There is a theory that the selection of this land was based on the Four Gods corresponding to Feng Shui, which was transmitted from China.
The area of Heian-kyo is smaller than the current Kyoto city.
The northernmost main road is Ichijo Street, located between Imadegawa Street and Marutamachi Street.

Emperor Kanmu moved the capital to Yamashiro Province in 784 and built Nagaoka-kyo.

The Nihon Koki is an official history book compiled in the early Heian period, and is the third of the six national histories following the Nihon Shoki.
Completed in the 7th year of Jōwa (840), it covers a period of 42 years from the 11th year of Enryaku (792) to the 10th year of Tenchō (833).
The editor is Fujiwara no Tsugutsugu and others.
According to the preface, in the 10th year of Konin (819), Emperor Saga ordered Fujiwara no Fuyutsugu, Fujiwara no Otsugu, Fujiwara no Sadatsugu, and Yoshimine Yasuyo to compile the text.

Three people, excluding the unfinished Prince Michizane, died, so Emperor Junna later ordered Kiyohara Natsuno, Prince Naoyuki, Fujiwara Yoshino, Ono Minomori, Sakagami Imotsugu, and Shimada Kiyota to continue.
During the reign of Emperor Nimmyo, further edicts were issued commanding Fujiwara no Otsugu, Minamoto Tsunemoto, Fujiwara Yoshino, Fujiwara Yoshifusa, and Asano Shikatori to carry out their duties.
Furthermore, they added Furutakaniwa and Yamada Furutsugu, and finally reported the completion on December 9, 841 (January 5, 841).
The period it took to compile was 21 years, and the only person who was involved in the project spanning three emperors was Fujiwara no Suketsugu.
Following the "Nihon Shoki," this text records the reigns of Emperor Heizei, Emperor Saga, and Emperor Junna during the reign of Emperor Kammu.

In the early 15th century, there were 40 volumes, but they were lost over time. Later, a disciple of Hani Ho Kiichi, Inayama Yukinori, discovered a manuscript of 10 volumes at the Sanjo Nishi family, and it was published for the first time. (There is also a theory that it was edited by Yanagihara Norimitsu.)
The existing volumes are volumes 5, 8, 12, 13 (Kammu), 14, 17 (Heijou), 20, 21, 22, 24 (Saga), totaling 10 volumes, with the reign of Emperor Junna completely missing.
It is possible to partially reconstruct the text from the excerpt version of the Six National Histories, "Nihon Ki Ryaku," and the classification of the Six National Histories in "Ruiju Kokushi."

There are "Nihon Isshi" and "Nihon Koki Ibun" which collect various excerpts from different places, based on which, the following Shueisha translated and annotated Japanese historical materials and the Kodansha Academic Bunko have been published.
It is said that the content most reflects the opinion of Fujiwara no Michitsugu.

Adding short biographies (obituaries) to the death articles of the Emperor and court officials is in line with the "Continuation of Japanese Chronicles," and is the same as other subsequent historical books.

However, the obituary in this book does not flow into one-sided, official praise or criticism, but rather contains many interesting descriptions that include unique criticisms and impressions, making it unique in the Rikkokushi for maintaining a critical spirit.

Ashikaga Yoshiteru was the 15th shogun of the Muromachi shogunate and the last shogun of the Muromachi shogunate (reign: Eiroku 11 (1568) - Tensho 16 (1588)).
The father was the 12th shogun of the Muromachi shogunate, Ashikaga Yoshiharu.
The mother is Keijuin, the daughter of Konoe Hisamichi.
The 13th shogun, Ashikaga Yoshiteru, is a half-brother.
At first, he was a monk, but when Yoshiteru was assassinated by Matsunaga Hisahide and others, he escaped from Kyoto with the help of Hosokawa Yusai and other vassals.
Supported by Oda Nobunaga of Mino Province, he went up to Kyoto and became the 15th shogun.
Eventually, he came into conflict with Nobunaga and, in conjunction with Takeda Shingen and Asakura Yoshikage, established a siege network against Nobunaga.
At one point, Nobunaga was cornered, but eventually he was expelled from Kyoto by Nobunaga, and the Muromachi shogunate was effectively destroyed.
After that, he spent his remaining years with the support of Motonari Mōri and then Toyotomi Hideyoshi.
He was born on November 13, 1537, as the second son of the 12th shogun, Ashikaga Yoshiharu.

Because there was a legitimate child of his older brother, Ashikaga Yoshiteru, he became an adopted child of his maternal grandfather, Konoe Hisatsugu, at a young age and entered the Buddhist priesthood (Kofukuji Ichijo-in) under the name Kakukei.
He later advanced to the position of Gonsoshosu at Kofukuji Temple.

In the Eiroku Incident of Eiroku 8 (1565), the 13th shogun, my brother Yoshiteru, was assassinated by Matsunaga Hisahide and the Sanjo Sanetomi, and my younger brother, Ashikaga Shusonin, who was the head of the Rokuonin, was also lured to his death.

At this time, Yoshiaki was also captured by Matsunaga Hisahide and others, and imprisoned in Kofukuji Temple. (It is said that Hisahide and others feared turning Kofukuji Temple into an enemy by killing Yoshiaki, as Yoshiaki was the younger brother of the shogun and had been promised the position of head priest of Kofukuji Temple in the future).

However, with the help of vassals such as Hosokawa Yusai and Wada Yosimasa, he managed to escape and on February 17, 1566, in the 9th year of the Eiroku era, he returned to secular life and took the name Yoshiaki.
In the book that describes Yoshiaki, it is written that he was also known by the alias of "Buke Gosho" and other names.
When he was driven out of Kyoto, he was attacked by night thieves and was also known as the "Poor Governor".
On April 21st, he was secretly promoted to Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade, and appointed as Left Chamberlain.

There are opinions questioning the timing of the appointment, but according to Yamashina Genkitsu's "Genkitsu-kyo Ki", it is clear that he had already received the appointment before the day of the appointment of the shogun to Ashikaga Yoshihide, the rival of Yoshiteru, which took place in February of the 11th year of Eiroku (1568). On the day of the shogun's appointment, a messenger from Yoshihide appeared at Genkitsu's residence, who was the messenger of the appointment, asking for assistance in recommending his promotion to Jushi-shita, causing confusion.

Yoshiaki, who escaped from Kyoto, initially relied on the father and son, Rokkaku Yoshiyoshi and Rokkaku Yoshiharu of Omi Province, but Yoshiharu secretly colluded with the Sanjo Trio, so in August he fled to the domain of his sister's husband, Takeda Yoshitsugu in Wakasa Province.

However, the Wakasa Takeda clan did not have enough power to go up to Kyoto due to struggles for succession and power struggles among senior vassals. In September, they fled to the Asakura Yoshikage in Echizen Province and requested assistance in restoring the shogunate.

However, Yoshikage Asakura already had the "Kuritani Gosho" branch of the Ashikaga Shogunate, and Ashikaga Tsugutomo also had no intention of actively going up to the capital with Ashikaga Yoshiaki, who had just returned to secular life, so the journey to the capital did not materialize.

The role of Kanmuriyaku is being held by Asakura Yoshikage (note that there is no official historical document confirming that Yoshiaki had undergone the formal coming-of-age ceremony up to this point, making it unusually late for the time).
Eventually, with the mediation of Akechi Mitsuhide, a senior vassal of the Asakura family, he moved to Mino Province to seek the help of Oda Nobunaga.
In September of the 11th year of Eiroku (1568), he was enthroned by Oda Nobunaga and went up to Kyoto.
On October 18th, he received the appointment as the 15th shogun from the Imperial Court.
At the same time, he was promoted to Jushi-i no ge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade) and appointed as Sangi (Councilor) and Left Guard Middle General.

Enryaku-ji is a temple located in Sakamoto Honmachi, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture, with the entire Mount Hiei at an elevation of 848 meters as its precincts.
Rather than being called by the name of Enryaku-ji, it is often referred to as Mount Hiei, or Hiei-zan.
It was located north of Heian-kyo (Kyoto) and was also known as Hokurei.
This is the head temple of the Japanese Tendai sect, founded by the monk Saicho in the early Heian period (767-822).
The abbot (kanju) is called the Tendai Zasu and oversees the branch temples.
Since the founding of Kukai, it has been a center of Heian Buddhism alongside Mount Koya's Kongobuji Temple.

In addition to the teachings of the Tendai Lotus Sutra, esoteric Buddhism, Zen (meditation and insight), and chanting of the Buddha's name were also practiced, giving the appearance of a comprehensive Buddhist university. During the Heian period, it gained great power and received the respect of the imperial family and nobility.

In particular, the ritual prayers performed by esoteric Buddhism gained the support of the aristocracy in the Heian period, and the esoteric Buddhism of Enryaku-ji Temple competed with the esoteric Buddhism of To-ji Temple (Taimitsu) within the Shingon sect.

"Enryaku-ji" refers to the total of the three towers and sixteen valleys, such as the East Tower, West Tower, and Yokogawa, scattered in the precincts from the mountaintop of Mt. Hiei to the eastern foot.
In the 7th year of Enryaku (788), Saicho established a small hermitage called Ichijo Shikan-in, marking the beginning.
The temple name "Enryaku-ji," taken from the era name at its founding, was granted in the 14th year of the Kōnin era (824 AD) after the death of Saichō.

Enryaku-ji Temple has produced numerous famous monks, including Ennin and Enchin who laid the foundation of Japanese Tendai Buddhism, Ryōnin the founder of the Yūzū Nembutsu school, Hōnen the founder of Jōdo-shū, Shinran the founder of Jōdo Shinshū, Eisai the founder of Rinzai Zen, Dōgen the founder of Sōtō Zen, and Nichiren the founder of Nichiren Buddhism. Many founders of new Buddhist sects and famous monks in Japanese Buddhist history have trained on Mount Hiei in their youth, earning it the nickname "Mother Mountain of Japanese Buddhism."
Mount Hiei appears in many literary works.

In addition, rigorous ascetic practices such as the "12-year mountain retreat" and the "1000-day pilgrimage to sacred peaks" have been continued to the present day, and as a representative sacred site of Japanese Buddhism, it is also registered as a World Cultural Heritage Site by UNESCO.

Mount Hiei is a mountain whose name is mentioned in the "Kojiki", and it is believed to have been a mountain of mountain worship since ancient times. At the Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine in Sakamoto at the eastern foot of the mountain, the deity Oyamazumi no Kami, the landlord deity of Mount Hiei, is enshrined.

Saicho's secular name was Mitsunobu Hirono, and he was born in the second year of Tenpyo Jingo (766 AD) in Shiga District, Omi Province (Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture). (There is also a theory that he was born in 767 AD).
At the age of 15 in the 11th year of the Hōki era (780), he received ordination (became a monk) under the guidance of the monk Gyōhyō at Ōmi Kokubun-ji Temple, and took the name Saichō.
At the age of 20, in the fourth year of Enryaku (785), he received ordination at Todai-ji Temple in Nara and became a formal monk.

Young Masumi, for various reasons, did not seek a stable position at the grand temple in Nara, but instead secluded himself on Mount Hiei near his hometown, dedicating himself to training and studying scriptures.

Saicho considered the teachings of the Lotus Sutra to be the highest among the many scriptures, and studied the "Three Great Sections of the Lotus Sutra" (Hokke Gengi, Hokke Monju, Makashikan) written by the Chinese Tendai master Chigi.

In the 7th year of Enryaku (788), Saicho established a small temple consisting of a Yakushi Hall, Monju Hall, and Sutra Repository at the current location of the Konpon Chudo, naming it Ichijo Shikan-in.
This temple is also called Mt. Hiei Temple, and the temple name "Enryaku-ji" with an era name was permitted after the death of Saicho, in the 14th year of the Kōnin era (824 AD).

During the reign of Emperor Kanmu, Saicho relied on him and received assistance from the Emperor and the Waki clan, and as a result, Mount Hiei Temple gradually prospered as a dojo for national protection guarding the northeast of Kyoto.
In the 21st year of Enryaku (802), Saicho was permitted to travel to Tang as a returning student (short-term overseas training student).
In the 23rd year of Enryaku (804 AD), I crossed over to Tang on a ship as part of a diplomatic mission.

Saicho visited the sacred site of Mount Hiei and studied Tendai teachings and Mahayana Bodhisattva precepts under the guidance of the Tendai master Doshu and the Tendai teachings from the head monk Gyomanza.
In addition, at the Longxing Temple in Yuezhou (Shaoxing), they are studying esoteric Buddhism from Shunxiao Ajari and Zen from Shakunen Zenji.

There is a story in the Nihon Shoki about the killing of the Ho-shoku god, so although generally considered a male god, there is no description in the Kojiki or Nihon Shoki that determines the gender.

In the myths of other countries, the moon god is often depicted as a goddess, and there are also many goddesses with aggressive personalities in other countries' myths. Therefore, some scholars argue for the goddess theory, stating that the story of Susanoo killing the food goddess cannot be definitively attributed to a male god.
Tsukuyomi is considered the god of the moon, but there are various differences in his divinity depending on the literature.

In the Kojiki, it is said that Izanagi was born from his right eye when he escaped from Yomi and performed purification, and Amaterasu, born from his other eye, and Susanoo, born from his nose, together form the three noble children.

On the other hand, in the "Nihon Shoki," there is a story that she was born from the left eye, contrary to the "Kojiki," and another story that she emerged from a white bronze mirror held in her right hand, with her dominion not limited to the heavens or the sea.
Tsukuyomi is born in opposition to Amaterasu, who symbolizes the sun, but in the field of comparative mythology, it is pointed out that similar ideas exist in various myths.

For example, in the Chinese legend of Pangu (as recorded in the "Chronicles of the Five Phases"), it is said that after Pangu died, his left eye became the sun and his right eye became the moon. Similarly, in Greek mythology, the sun god Apollo and the moon goddess Artemis are considered twins.
However, Apollo was originally a separate god from the sun god Helios, and the identification of the two came later.

In addition, in the Book of Genesis in the Old Testament, on the fourth day of creation, God created "two great lights" in the sky, namely the sun and the moon, to govern the day and night respectively, and to separate light from darkness. This is the creation of the sun and moon, as told in the Bible.
The birth of Amaterasu and Tsukuyomi is also thought to follow the pattern of a common worldwide myth of the origin of the sun and moon as a pair.

In Japanese mythology, Tsukuyomi is considered an important god alongside Amaterasu and Susanoo, but he does not appear much in the myths of the Kojiki and Nihon Shoki, and is generally lacking in activity.
It is only briefly mentioned in the "Nihon Shoki" Book Five, Section Eleven, that the origin of grains is discussed.
There is a theory that balance is achieved by placing a god who does nothing between the contrasting personalities of Amaterasu and Susanoo.
Similar structures can also be seen in the relationship between Takamimusubi and Kamimusubi, as well as between Hoori (Yamato Takeru) and Hoderi (Umisachi-hiko).
This is called the hollow structure in Japanese mythology.
Some people argue for the theory of the same god because the domains and episodes of Susanoo overlap in part.
In the first volume of the Kojiki, it is said that when Izanagi washed his right eye, Amaterasu and Susanoo were born along with him, and they are called the "Three Precious Children."
Tsukuyomi is ordered to "inform the Night Eating Country," but there is no further activity after this.
There is also a theory that there is a country called Yomi where the goddess Izanami resides.

In the fifth section of the Age of the Gods in the Nihon Shoki, it is briefly stated that "a god of the moon, shining brightly after the sun, was born and sent to the heavens to rule alongside the sun." However, in the following first book, there is a different account where Izanagi no Mikoto gave birth to Omoikane no Mikoto holding a white bronze mirror in his left hand, and Tsukuyomi no Mikoto holding a white bronze mirror in his right hand.

There are several stories in which it is instructed to rule the heavens alongside Amaterasu-Omikami in the domain of dominion, while there is also a story in which it is commanded to control the eight hundred layers of the tides of the vast sea plain (this seems to have come from the idea that the moon controls the tides), and multiple stories of the birth of three gods are parallel.

In the fifth paragraph of the Kojiki, it is said that Amaterasu-Omikami and Tsukuyomi-no-Mikoto were both ordered to rule the heavens together. However, later Tsukuyomi-no-Mikoto received an order to meet with Uke Mochi in the heavens and descended to meet with Uke Mochi.
In response, the god of food and agriculture vomited rice from his mouth, which angered Tsukuyomi-no-Mikoto, who then killed the god of food and agriculture with a sword, calling him "disgusting."
From the corpse of the food god, cows, horses, silkworms, rice, and other things were born, and this became the origin of grains.
Onmyoji (onmyoji, onyoji) is one of the official positions belonging to the Onmyoryo of the Nakatsukasasho under the Ritsuryo system in ancient Japan.

It refers to the position of a skilled official (technician) who performs divination, geomancy, and other tasks based on the Yin-Yang Five Elements philosophy, and is later responsible for overseeing divination, sorcery, and all aspects of rituals beyond the original Ritsuryo regulations.

Since the Middle Ages, it has come to refer mainly to non-official individuals who personally practice divination, sorcery, and rituals in various places, and in modern times it is defined as a type of priest who performs private prayers and divination in the private sector.
It is sometimes pronounced as "onyoji" without linking sounds.

It is believed that all phenomena are based on the combination of Yin-Yang and Five Elements ideology, which began in ancient China during the Xia and Shang dynasties and was almost completed during the Zhou dynasty. Astronomy, calendars, divination, and timekeeping, which are closely related to this ideology, were transmitted directly from mainland China (Han and Sui dynasties) or through the western regions of the Korean Peninsula (Goguryeo and Baekje) to Japan by the Asuka period in the 5th to 6th centuries, at the latest by the arrival of the Five Classics scholars from Baekje in 512 (7th year of Emperor Keitai) or the arrival of the Yi scholars in 554 (15th year of Emperor Kinmei).

Initially, the influence of these various studies on politics and culture was minimal, but in 602 AD (the 10th year of Empress Suiko), Kanro, who became a pioneer of Onmyodo in Japan, came from Baekje and began teaching various studies to 34 selected bureaucrats, including Prince Shotoku, which started to have a significant impact on our country's politics.

For the first time in Japan, the calendar (Genka calendar) was adopted as the official calendar, and in order to absorb Buddhist teachings, Yin-Yang Five Elements philosophy, and calendar methods, an envoy was sent to Sui, an advanced civilization country, in 607 (15th year of Empress Suiko). In addition, the influence of Yin-Yang Five Elements philosophy became prominent in the establishment of Prince Shotoku's Seventeen-Article Constitution and the Twelve-Rank Cap System.

Afterwards, the imperial court continued to send exchange students with the missions to Sui (later Tang) dynasty, and also invited numerous monks or scholars from the western coast of the Korean Peninsula or mainland China to further absorb knowledge.

As the introduction of various studies progresses, it has become important in Japan to consider the movements and positions of the sun, moon, stars, and planets, and to predict the future by judging good and bad luck based on the theory of the mutual generation and restraint of the five elements, in order to obtain guidance for various matters and determine good and bad fortune. As a strategy to judge good and bad luck and obtain a code of conduct, the Yin-Yang and Five Elements theory has come to be emphasized.

In the 7th century, Emperor Tenmu, who was a master of astrology and had a deep understanding of yin-yang and the five elements, personally took a divination during the Jinshin War and established the "Onmyoryo" and Japan's first observatory in 676 (the 4th year of Emperor Tenmu).

In the year 685 (13th year of the Tenmu Emperor), the term "Onmyoji" began to be used, and the Yin-Yang Five Elements philosophy became even more popular. In the Yoro Ritsuryo of 718, the establishment of the Onmyo-ryo as a bureau within the Nakatsukasa-sho was formalized, with the appointment of officials such as astronomers, Onmyoji, calendar experts, and timekeepers. Alongside the Kiboku of the Jingikan, they were responsible for conducting official divination ceremonies.

Those in charge of technology brought from the continent are responsible for various scholars and onmyoji, who are proficient in Chinese literature and have expertise in reading Chinese texts. They are mainly immigrants from mainland China, including the former Han, later Han, Sui dynasties that dominated the mainland, Goguryeo and Baekje that had influence on the western coast of the Korean Peninsula, and occasionally scholars who returned from Silla, which initially had influence on the eastern coast of the Korean Peninsula.

In particular, following the defeat in the Battle of Baekgang in 663 AD (Year 2 of the reign of Emperor Tenji), in which Japan sent reinforcements to its close ally Baekje, Silla unified the Korean Peninsula after the downfall of the Baekje dynasty. Many scholars from Baekje immigrated as refugees during this period, and a large number of them were appointed to official positions.

The original techniques of the Onmyoryo at the time of its establishment were purely divination, feng shui (similar to what is now called "geomancy"), astronomical observation, astrology, calendar creation, determination of auspicious and inauspicious days, and the management of the calendar. Therefore, they mainly predicted astronomical observations, calendar management, and the auspiciousness of events based on theoretical analysis according to the principles of Yin and Yang, without performing any religious rituals or sorcery like Shinto priests or monks. However, they played an important role in selecting auspicious days for construction work at the imperial court, as well as in determining the auspiciousness of locations and directions during events such as the relocation of the capital.
